%%sql
-- creating a database for logical organization
CREATE DATABASE IF NOT EXISTS MusicService
## Set the database as the session context
## Using Python to list file system contents
Always good to get used to reading and referencing docs: https://hadoop.apache.org/docs/current/api/org/apache/hadoop/fs/FileStatus.html

path = "/musicdata/"
fs = spark._jvm.org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem.get(spark._jsc.hadoopConfiguration())
list_status = fs.listStatus(spark._jvm.org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path(path))
result = [file.getPath().getName() for file in list_status]

for filename in result:
    print(filename)
## Inside Synapse you can find preconfigured Microsoft utilities
## Create Spark dataframes based on the files

# load data into a dataframe from Parquet
artist_plays = spark.read.load('abfss://synapse@warnerdatalake.dfs.core.windows.net/musicdata/userartistplays.parquet', format='parquet')
artist_plays.show()

# load data into a dataframe from csv
artist_ticket_sales = spark.read.load('/partnerData/artistTicketSales.csv', format='csv', header=True)
artist_ticket_sales.show()
artist_ticket_sales.printSchema()

source: ## You can convert into a Pandas (single-node) dataframe and use that library
## You can add Python libraries to your cluster

from pandas_profiling import ProfileReport

profile = ProfileReport(ats_pandas, title='Artist Tickets - Pandas Profiling Report', explorative=True)
displayHTML(profile.to_html())
## But what about output to a single file?
## Writing an exact file is usually handled through platform or OS commands
## Specify a schema to apply to the file

#specify the schema
from pyspark.sql.types import *

customSchema = StructType([
    StructField("UserID", StringType(), True),        
    StructField("Gender", StringType(), True),
    StructField("Age", IntegerType(), True),
    StructField("Country", StringType(), True),
    StructField("SignupString", StringType(), True),
])

user_details = spark.read.load('abfss://synapse@warnerdatalake.dfs.core.windows.net/musicdata/UserDetails.csv', 
format="csv", header="true", sep=',', schema=customSchema)
## Convert the Signup string to a real date

from pyspark.sql.functions import to_date

user_details_conv = user_details.withColumn('SignupDate',to_date(user_details.SignupString, 'MMM dd, yyyy'))
#below is the result
user_details_conv.printSchema()
user_details_conv.select('SignupString','SignupDate').show(10,False)

## Problem is, from the Spark docs:
"Each line must contain a separate, self-contained valid JSON object."

from pyspark.sql.functions import explode

user_details_json_flat = user_details_json.select(explode('ServiceUsers').alias('users_flat'))
user_details_json_flat.show(5)
user_details_json_flat.printSchema()

from pyspark.sql.functions import col
user_details_tabular = user_details_json_flat.select(col("users_flat.UserID").alias("UserID"),col("users_flat.Age").alias("Age"),col("users_flat.Country").alias("Country"))
user_details_tabular.show(10)

import xml.etree.ElementTree as ET
from itertools import islice

root = ET.fromstring(xmltext)

for child in islice(root, 5):
    print(child.tag, child.attrib)

print("One user:" + root[0].get("UserID"))

users = []
for index, child in enumerate(root):
    user = [child.get("UserID"),child.get("Gender"),child.get("Age"),child.get("Country"),child.get("SignupString")]
    users.append(user)

print("length of users array: " + str(len(users)))

# applying transformations
# saving the transforms into another dataframe and save as managed table
platform_artist_performance = spark.sql("""
  SELECT Artist, SUM(Plays) AS total_plays
FROM user_artist_plays
GROUP BY Artist
ORDER BY SUM(Plays) DESC 
""")

platform_artist_performance.write.saveAsTable("platform_artist_performance")

source: ## Let's DML on a Spark table
INSERT INTO platform_artist_performance SELECT t.* FROM (SELECT 'NewArtist' Artist,0 total_plays) t
UPDATE platform_artist_performance set total_plays=1 where Artist='NewArtist'
## In vanilla Spark overwriting is the only way to Update or Delete but that's a lot of work!

artist_plays = spark.sql("""
SELECT UserID, CASE Artist 
            WHEN 'p.o.d.' THEN 'p.o.d' 
            WHEN 'b.o.b.' THEN 'b.o.b' 
            ELSE Artist 
            END as Artist, Plays FROM user_artist_plays
## Now we can delete or update by manipulating the partitions

from pyspark.sql.functions import lit

artist_plays_clutch = spark.table("usersartistplays_partitioned").where("Artist ='clutch'")
artist_plays_clutch.show()
artist_plays_clutch = artist_plays_clutch.select("UserID",lit(0).alias("Plays"),"Artist")
artist_plays_clutch.show()
artist_plays_clutch.createOrReplaceTempView("artist_plays_clutch")

%%sql
INSERT OVERWRITE TABLE usersartistplays_partitioned PARTITION (Artist = "clutch")
    SELECT UserID, Plays FROM artist_plays_clutch

%%sql
CREATE TABLE artist_plays_clutch_temp
AS
SELECT * FROM artist_plays_clutch

%%sql
INSERT OVERWRITE TABLE usersartistplays_partitioned PARTITION (Artist = "clutch")
    SELECT UserID, Plays FROM artist_plays_clutch_temp

%%sql
SELECT * FROM usersartistplays_partitioned WHERE Artist='clutch'
LIMIT 100

%%sql
SELECT * FROM usersartistplays_partitioned WHERE Artist="atmosphere"
LIMIT 10

%%sql 
-- unpartitioned
SELECT * from userartistplays_unmgd
WHERE Artist='adele'
LIMIT 10

%%sql
-- test the partitioning
SELECT * from usersartistplays_partitioned
WHERE Artist='adele'
LIMIT 10

spark.sql("""SELECT * from usersartistplays_partitioned
WHERE Artist='adele'
LIMIT 10""").explain()

source: ALTER TABLE platform_artist_performance ADD COLUMNS (albumCount int)
## If you REALLY want to drop a column, then no choice but to overwrite (homework for the student :D)
## You can define views as well

%%sql
-- note there isn't something like dataframe.createOrReplacePermanentView()
CREATE VIEW vw_userdetailspercountry AS 
SELECT count(UserId) usercount,avg(Age) avg_age,Max(Age) max_age,Min(Age) min_age FROM user_details
GROUP BY Country

spark.sql("""CREATE VIEW vw_userdetailspercountry2 AS 
SELECT count(UserId) usercount,avg(Age) avg_age,Max(Age) max_age,Min(Age) min_age FROM user_details
GROUP BY Country""")

%%sql
select * from vw_userdetailspercountry
order by usercount desc
## With some research you can easily process almost any file type

from pyspark.ml.image import ImageSchema

image_df = ImageSchema.readImages("/musicdata/albumImages/")
image_df.printSchema()
image_df.select("image.origin","image.height","image.width").show()

## Cache and persist
This is critical to understand when dealing with true big data

# this is equivalent to persist(MEMORY_AND_DISK)
user_details_df = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM user_details")
user_details_df.cache() #this is lazy caching
user_details_df.count() # this action pulls the data

## Persist levels
MEMORY_ONLY – This is the default behavior of the RDD cache() method and stores the RDD or DataFrame as deserialized objects to JVM memory. When there is no enough memory available it will not save DataFrame of some partitions and these will be re-computed as and when required. This takes more memory. but unlike RDD, this would be slower than MEMORY_AND_DISK level as it recomputes the unsaved partitions and recomputing the in-memory columnar representation of the underlying table is expensive

MEMORY_ONLY_SER – This is the same as MEMORY_ONLY but the difference being it stores RDD as serialized objects to JVM memory. It takes lesser memory (space-efficient) then MEMORY_ONLY as it saves objects as serialized and takes an additional few more CPU cycles in order to deserialize.

MEMORY_ONLY_2 – Same as MEMORY_ONLY storage level but replicate each partition to two cluster nodes.

MEMORY_ONLY_SER_2 – Same as MEMORY_ONLY_SER storage level but replicate each partition to two cluster nodes.

MEMORY_AND_DISK – This is the default behavior of the DataFrame or Dataset. In this Storage Level, The DataFrame will be stored in JVM memory as a deserialized objects. When required storage is greater than available memory, it stores some of the excess partitions into disk and reads the data from disk when it required. It is slower as there is I/O involved.

MEMORY_AND_DISK_SER – This is same as MEMORY_AND_DISK storage level difference being it serializes the DataFrame objects in memory and on disk when space not available.

MEMORY_AND_DISK_2 – Same as MEMORY_AND_DISK storage level but replicate each partition to two cluster nodes.

MEMORY_AND_DISK_SER_2 – Same as MEMORY_AND_DISK_SER storage level but replicate each partition to two cluster nodes.

DISK_ONLY – In this storage level, DataFrame is stored only on disk and the CPU computation time is high as I/O involved.

DISK_ONLY_2 – Same as DISK_ONLY storage level but replicate each partition to two cluster nodes.

from pyspark import StorageLevel

user_details_df.unpersist()
user_details_df.persist(StorageLevel.DISK_ONLY)
user_details_df.count()
## You can cache in SQL too

source:
%%sql
SELECT sum(plays) allPlays, Artist 
FROM usersartistplays_partitioned
GROUP BY Artist

from hyperspace import *

# Create an instance of Hyperspace
hyperspace = Hyperspace(spark)
# Enable Hyperspace
Hyperspace.enable(spark)

artist_plays_hyper = spark.read.load('abfss://synapse@warnerdatalake.dfs.core.windows.net/musicdata/userartistplays.parquet', 
format='parquet')
artist_plays_hyper.createOrReplaceTempView("vw_artistPlaysHyper")

user_details_hyper = spark.read.load('abfss://synapse@warnerdatalake.dfs.core.windows.net/musicdata/UserDetails.csv', 
format="csv", header="true", sep=',')
user_details_hyper.createOrReplaceTempView("vw_userDetailsHyper")

%%sql
SELECT vap.Artist, vap.Plays, vdh.Country from vw_artistPlaysHyper vap join vw_userDetailsHyper vdh 
on vap.UserID=vdh.UserID
WHERE Artist='clutch'
ORDER BY Plays DESC
LIMIT 10

querydf = spark.sql('''SELECT vap.Artist, vap.Plays, vdh.Country from vw_artistPlaysHyper vap join vw_userDetailsHyper vdh 
on vap.UserID=vdh.UserID
WHERE Artist="clutch"
ORDER BY Plays DESC
LIMIT 10''')

spark.conf.set("spark.hyperspace.explain.displayMode", "html")
hyperspace.explain(querydf, True, displayHTML)

from pyspark.sql.types import StructField, StructType, StringType, IntegerType

uap_schema = StructType([StructField('UserID', StringType(), True), 
StructField('Artist', StringType(), True), StructField('Plays', IntegerType(), True)])

extra_userArtistPlays = [("UserID1", "New Artist", 100), ("UserID2", "New Artist", 100)]

extra_userArtistPlays_df = spark.createDataFrame(extra_userArtistPlays, uap_schema)

artist_plays_hyper = artist_plays_hyper.union(extra_userArtistPlays_df)

hyperspace.refreshIndex("artistPlaysIndex","incremental")
